paper_id: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments

paper_metadata.title: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments
paper_metadata.research_focus: Potassium balance and related changes in soils under different fertilization treatments in long-term field experiments.
paper_metadata.soil_k_relevance: The study's central focus is on soil potassium, including its balance, inputs, outputs, various pool characterizations (exchangeable, non-exchangeable, bioavailable), recovery rates, and changes over time under different management practices.

research_context.study_objectives: To determine the potassium balance and related changes in soils at different fertilization treatments.
research_context.soil_k_research_role: Soil potassium is the primary subject of investigation, with the research aiming to understand its dynamics and availability under various long-term agricultural management scenarios.
research_context.geographic_setting: Two sites in the Czech Republic: Hněvčeves (50°18'46''N, 15°43'3''E, 265 m a.s.l.) and Humpolec (49°33'16''N, 15°21'2''E, 525 m a.s.l.).
research_context.environmental_conditions: Different soil and climatic conditions at the two sites. Hněvčeves: Mean annual temperature 8.2°C, mean annual precipitation 573 mm. Humpolec: Mean annual temperature 7.0°C, mean annual precipitation 665 mm.
research_context.agricultural_context: Intensive farming systems typical for the Czech Republic. Crop rotation: potatoes-winter wheat-spring barley, with all three crops grown each year.
research_context.study_design: Long-term stationary field experiments established in 1996, running for 21 years. Six fertilization treatments: (1) no fertilization (control); (2) farmyard manure (FYM 1); (3) half dose of farmyard manure + nitrogen (N) in mineral nitrogen fertilizers (FYM 1/2); (4) mineral nitrogen fertilizers (N); (5) NPK in mineral fertilizers (NPK); (6) straw of spring barley + N in mineral nitrogen fertilizers (N + ST). Soil samples were taken from the 0–30 cm depth with four replications, specifically from plots with spring barley.
research_context.temporal_scope: 21 years (1996–2017). Soil samples were analyzed from the beginning (autumn 1996, before experiment establishment) and the end (2017, after plant harvest at the end of the 7th crop rotation).
research_context.spatial_scope: Two distinct experimental sites (Hněvčeves and Humpolec), with plot-level measurements (four replications per treatment).

concentration_measurements.sample_context: Plough layer (0-30 cm), average of all treatments

statistical_measures.comparison: Significantly lower compared to other extraction methods

statistical_measures.comparison: Significantly lower compared to other extraction methods

concentration_measurements.parameter: Total K extracted by boiling HNO3
Total K extracted by boiling HNO3

pool_characterizations.analytical_method: Boiling 1 mol/L HNO3 extraction minus NH4OAc-determined K
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Significant tendency to decrease at variants without K fertilization over 21 years

treatment_effects.Humpolec: No significant impact of fertilization on changes over 21 years

pool_characterizations.analytical_method: Boiling 1 mol/L HNO3 extraction minus NH4OAc-determined K
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: No significant impact of fertilization on changes over 21 years

treatment_effects.Humpolec: No significant impact of fertilization on changes over 21 years

pool_characterizations.pool_type: Saturation of potassium in cation exchange capacity (CEC)
pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Plough layer (0-30 cm), average of all treatments

pool_characterizations.pool_type: Saturation of potassium in cation exchange capacity (CEC)
pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Plough layer (0-30 cm), average of all treatments

process_rates.process: Potassium recovery rate from farmyard manure by crops
process_rates.measurement_approach: Calculated from K input and crop uptake

process_rates.process: Potassium recovery rate from mineral fertilizers by crops
process_rates.measurement_approach: Calculated from K input and crop uptake

temporal_patterns.monitoring_frequency: Soil samples taken at the beginning (1996) and end (2017) of the 21-year period. Plant yields and K content measured annually.

long_term_trends.trend_description: Significant tendency to decrease in variants without K fertilization.
No significant impact of fertilization on changes.

between_site_differences.site_comparison: Hněvčeves (200 mg K/kg) vs. Humpolec (157 mg K/kg)
Hněvčeves (206 mg K/kg) vs. Humpolec (153 mg K/kg)
Hněvčeves (816-927 mg K/kg) vs. Humpolec (2908-3068 mg K/kg)
explanatory_factors: Soil-forming materials (paragneiss at Humpolec vs. loess at Hněvčeves)

between_site_differences.site_comparison: Hněvčeves (110 mg K/kg) vs. Humpolec (120 mg K/kg)
explanatory_factors: Different character of clay particles at the two sites
Differences between total values of cation exchange capacity (Hněvčeves: 116 mmol+/kg, Humpolec: 90 mmol+/kg)

difference_magnitude.Humpolec_higher_by: 348 kg K/ha on average for all variants over 21 years

explanatory_factors: Higher precipitation and its regular distribution throughout the vegetation period at Humpolec

cycling_processes.description: Addition of potassium to the soil system through fertilization.
Removal of potassium from the soil system by harvested crops.
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Determined by yields and K content in plants

cycling_processes.description: Transfer of K from less available (non-exchangeable) to more available pools.
controlling_factors: Clay mineral type (2:1 types, mica, vermiculite)
Plant root exudates (H+ excretion in rhizosphere)
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Inferred from changes in non-exchangeable K and K balance discrepancies

plant_soil_interactions.description: Plants absorb K from soil solution, exchangeable K, and some part of non-exchangeable K.

quantitative_data.K uptake (Humpolec): Higher by 348 kg K/ha on average for all variants over 21 years compared to Hněvčeves

influencing_factors: Yields of crops (e.g., higher potato yield)
K content in plants (e.g., K content in straw and potato tubers differed between sites)
Environmental conditions (e.g., precipitation and its distribution)

plant_soil_interactions.description: In the plant rhizosphere, a zone poor in K is formed, leading plants to excrete H+ to the rhizosphere, which results in release of non-exchangeable K.
influencing_factors: Plant species (e.g., ryegrass mentioned in reference)

chemical_processes.characterization: Potassium is strongly sorbed in soils, influencing its utilization. Non-exchangeable K is bound mainly at boundaries of 2:1 clay minerals (mica and vermiculite).
chemical_processes.implications: Higher K utilization at soils with higher sorption capacity. Clay mineral type is more important than total clay content for non-exchangeable K binding.

soil_k_effects.K balance: Highly negative (-1124 to -1663 kg K/ha/21 years)

mechanisms: Continuous crop uptake without K replenishment

soil_k_effects.K balance: Positive (856 kg K/ha/21 years at Hněvčeves, 48 kg K/ha/21 years at Humpolec)

mechanisms: K not strongly sorbed in manure

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: Half dose of farmyard manure + mineral N (FYM 1/2)

soil_k_effects.Exchangeable K: Increased compared to unfertilized, but less than full FYM

mechanisms: Reduced K input compared to full FYM

soil_k_effects.K balance: Most negative (-1744 to -2376 kg K/ha/21 years)

mechanisms: K input (average 90 kg K/ha/year) but still insufficient to balance uptake

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: Straw of spring barley + mineral N (N + ST)

soil_k_effects.Exchangeable K: Lower than NPK, higher than N
soil_k_effects.K balance influence: Did not influence K balance positively

soil_k_impacts.Timing: Always applied in autumn (October) to potatoes.
soil_k_impacts.FYM: Significant increase of exchangeable K content, positive K balance.
soil_k_impacts.Straw: Did not positively influence K balance.

management_practices.implementation_details: FYM 1: 63.0 t/ha/3 years (Hněvčeves), 59.45 t/ha/3 years (Humpolec). Straw: incorporated with mineral N.
management_practices.spatial_effects: Observed at both Hněvčeves and Humpolec.

soil_k_impacts.P and K: Applied to each crop in autumn.
soil_k_impacts.N: Applied to potatoes and spring barley in spring; for winter wheat, dose divided into halves (BBCH 21, BBCH 31–32).
soil_k_impacts.NPK treatment: Negative K balance, but higher exchangeable K than N-only treatment.

management_practices.implementation_details: N: 140 kg N/ha (wheat), 70 kg N/ha (barley); FYM 1/2: 115 kg N/ha (wheat), 50 kg N/ha (barley). NPK: 30 kg P/ha, 100 kg K/ha (60% potassium salt).
management_practices.spatial_effects: Observed at both Hněvčeves and Humpolec.

comparative_analysis.comparison_type: K utilization from different fertilizer types
comparative_analysis.notes: Higher K utilization at soils with higher sorption capacity (Hněvčeves for mineral K). Higher utilization at lower application doses.

analytical_methods.procedure_description: 3.00 g air-dried soil sample (≤ 2 mm) weighed into 50 mL tubes. 30 mL solution of 0.01 mol/L CaCl2 and 0.01 mol/L 0.002 diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (DTPA) applied. Solution shaken for 1 h on a horizontal shaker. Extracts filtered.
analytical_methods.instrumentation: Optical emission spectrometer with inductive coupled plasma (ICP-OES, Agilent Technologies 700, Victoria, Australia)

analytical_methods.procedure_description: 3.00 g air-dried soil sample (≤ 2 mm) extracted with 30 mL solution of 0.02 mol/L CH3COOH, 0.25 mol/L NH4NO3, 0.015 mol/L NH4F, 0.013 mol/L HNO3, 0.001 mol/L ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA). Solution shaken for 5 min on a horizontal shaker and subsequently filtered.

Modified procedure by Haby et al. (1990). 3.00 g air-dried soil sample (≤ 2 mm) extracted with 30 mL 1 mol/L ammonium acetate solution at pH 7.00. Soil solution slurry shaken for 2 h, solution separated from solid by centrifugation.

Helmke and Sparks (2000) method. 2.5 g finely ground soil sample heated with 25 mL of 1 mol/L HNO3 in an Erlenmeyer flask on a hot plate for 10 min after boiling started. After cooling for 5 min, sample filtrated and extract diluted to 100 mL with 0.1 mol/L HNO3. Kne determined by subtracting NH4OAc-determined K from obtained values.
Samples of barley and wheat grain and straw, and potato tubers dried at 40°C and subsequently proceeded with dry decomposition (Mader et al. 1998).
analytical_methods.instrumentation: Atomic Adsorption Spectrometry (AA280FS, Agilent Technologies, Mulgrave, Australia)

sampling_design.spatial_sampling: Soil samples from 0–30 cm depth, four replications per treatment plot. Data evaluated based on soils taken from plots with spring barley.
sampling_design.temporal_sampling: Soil samples taken in autumn 1996 (before experiment establishing) and in 2017 (at the end of 7th crop rotation, shortly after plant harvest).
sampling_design.sample_processing: Air-dried soil samples (≤ 2 mm) for soil analyses. Finely ground soil for boiling HNO3 extraction. Plant samples dried at 40°C.
sampling_design.representativeness: Samples from plots with spring barley were used for evaluation.

method_comparisons: Comparison of Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc methods showed high similarity (Pearson’s correlation coefficient 0.989 at Hněvčeves, 0.958 at Humpolec, P < 0.001).
CAT extraction revealed significantly lower K content compared to other methods (60–65% compared to Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc).
The ratio of CAT values (Hněvčeves/Humpolec) was opposite compared to Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc methods.

climate_conditions.temperature: Hněvčeves: Mean annual 8.2°C; Humpolec: Mean annual 7.0°C
climate_conditions.precipitation: Hněvčeves: Mean annual 573 mm; Humpolec: Mean annual 665 mm
climate_conditions.seasonality: Regular distribution of precipitation at Humpolec noted as a positive influence on K uptake.

soil_properties.classification: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol; Humpolec: Stagnic Cambisol
soil_properties.texture: Hněvčeves: Clay loam; Humpolec: Sandy loam
soil_properties.mineralogy: Hněvčeves: on loess; Humpolec: on loess on paragneiss. Non-exchangeable K is bound mainly at boundaries of 2:1 clay minerals (mica and vermiculite). Clay mineral type is more important than total clay content.

landscape_context.topography: Hněvčeves: 265 m a.s.l.; Humpolec: 525 m a.s.l.
landscape_context.drainage: Not explicitly detailed, but precipitation distribution mentioned.
landscape_context.position: Not explicitly detailed beyond altitude and location.
landscape_context.land_use_history: Long-term field experiments (21 years) with specific crop rotation and fertilization history.

research_integration.relationship_to_other_measurements: Soil K balance and pool changes are directly related to crop yields and K content in harvested plants. Soil K levels are linked to fertilization intensity.
research_integration.integration_with_plant_studies: Plant K uptake is a critical component of the K balance calculation. Plant K content in grain, straw, and tubers was measured to determine K removal from the soil.
research_integration.connection_to_broader_objectives: The research contributes to understanding long-term sustainable soil management in the Czech Republic, especially concerning the low annual potassium doses in mineral fertilizers currently used.
research_integration.comparative_context: Results are compared with findings from other long-term field experiments in Europe (e.g., Bad Lauchstadt, Rothamsted) and other regions, particularly regarding non-exchangeable K dynamics and K utilization.
research_integration.literature_positioning: The study builds upon existing knowledge regarding K extraction methods (Egner-Riehm, Mehlich 3, CaCl2/DTPA, NH4OAc, boiling HNO3) and K cycling, emphasizing the importance of non-exchangeable K in long-term soil fertility.

methodological_constraints: The high agreement between Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc methods observed in this study might be lower in ordinary agricultural soils, suggesting the results are specific to these long-term field trials.

The study acknowledges that not all non-exchangeable K may be used by plants, as it is released continuously over many years, implying that short-term assessments might underestimate its long-term contribution.
interpretation_caveats: Discrepancies between calculated K balance (Table 3) and measured changes in soil K content (Table 6) are explained by continuous mobilization of potassium from non-exchangeable bonds and the unconsidered K content in the subsoil, which acts as a significant potassium source for plants.

extraction_assessment.extraction_notes: All explicit soil potassium-related information, including quantitative measurements, methodological details, and contextual factors, has been extracted. The provided table_data in the prompt was not directly parseable for quantitative values in figures, so all numerical data for figures was extracted from the descriptive text within the paper. All other tables (Table 1-6) were parsed for their data.
